awd_titl_txt: Foundations of Computational Mathematics Conference – FoCM 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The next triennial international conference in the series Foundations of Computational Mathematics, FoCM 2023, will be hosted at the Sorbonne University in Paris, France, June 12–21, 2023. The Foundations of Computational Mathematics (FoCM) conferences aim to be a main vehicle in the exploration of the broad interface between mathematics and contemporary computation, a subject area of importance both intellectually and for practical applications. It is expected that about 500 researchers will attend the conference from around the world, and about a third of them will be from the US. This project will partially cover travel and lodging costs for a diverse group of US researchers attending the conference. The majority of the funds will be distributed on a competitive basis to junior US participants, including graduate students, postdocs, and tenure track faculty.

The conference will follow the format of former FoCM conferences: plenary lectures in the mornings and theme-centered parallel workshops in the afternoons. Each workshop extends over three days, and the conference will consist of three periods, each period featuring 7 mathematically diverse but interconnected workshops, with 21 workshops in total. These activities combined with poster sessions and informal interactions among participants all synthesize forefront research with mentoring and training opportunities for young participants, helping them develop networks that include the world’s leading researchers. A number of themes connect the diverse workshop topics, such as learning from computation to automate, adapt and optimize the computational process which by itself becomes an analysis tool, ties from homotopy methods used in computational algebraic geometry for systems of algebraic equations and interior point methods in continuous optimization to numerical methods for differential equations and aspects of differential geometry, machine learning and signal processing cast as very large and challenging convex optimization problems, common themes among symbolic algorithms used for the solution of algebraic and differential equations, and relationships between decidability and tractability in real/complex arithmetic computational models and the Turing machine models considered in the context of combinatorics and intractability as well as discrete optimization.  More information about the FoCM 2023 conference can be found at https://focm2023.org

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project partially funded the participation of several US mathematicians in the Foundations of Computational Mathematics Conference - FoCM 2023 held at the Sorbonne University International Conference Center in Paris, France, in the period June 12-21, 2023. The project supported the travel of two of the plenary speakers from US: Carina Curto from Penn State and the Smale Prize recipient Shayan Oveis Gharan from University of Washington. The predominant portion of the funding was used to support 22 young researchers from the US: graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, tenure-track faculty, including members of groups that are under-represented in the mathematical sciences. The young scholars not only learned from senior researchers, but many were also afforded an opportunity to present their own research as well: eight of them gave invited talks, while eleven presented posters at different workshops. 

FoCM 2023 was a prestigious and effective forum for the dissemination of research across diverse fields within mathematics, capitalizing on the increasing interplay between mathematics and computation. The conference followed a format tried and tested to a great effect in former FoCM conferences: plenary lectures in the mornings and theme-centered parallel workshops in the afternoons. Each workshop extends over three days, and the conference consists of three periods, each featuring seven workshops. FoCM conferences uniquely integrate a web of inter-related disciplines within computational mathematics, inspiring multidisciplinary interaction across subjects and disciplines, in an informal and friendly atmosphere. Plenary and semi-plenary speakers prepare their talks to address not only specialists but a wider audience, allowing participants of the conference to attend talks in a variety of fields. The interdisciplinary nature of the conference is especially conducive for junior researchers to broadening their knowledge and interests.

More information about FoCM 2023 conference can be found at https://focm2023.org
